text: @GregHands. All I sadly got was, ‘my wife is German’.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The link to the map;
author: tnewtondunn

text: The smallest % of signatories seem to be in Remainer-turned-Leaver @mattwarman’s Boston and Skegness - less than 1 in 50 have signed.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Guess which constituency has the greatest % of Revoke A50 signatories? It’s @jeremycorbyn’s  - almost 1 in 5 have signed in Islington North so far. Oops.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
The geographical breakdown of the Revoke A50 petition. Strongest support: London, Oxford, Cambridge, M4 corridor and Scotland. Weakest: the Midlands, the North East, Welsh Valleys. 
A carbon copy of the referendum
author: tnewtondunn

text: No, that pretty much nails it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: With Theresa May's Premiership now in such serious jeopardy - some MPs think days away from ending - it's staggering not a single Cabinet minister has done any broadcast today to defend her. She's utterly alone.
author: tnewtondunn

text: To be (PM), or not to be (PM). To have an indicative vote, or to have an indicative vote thrust upon you.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And now...
author: tnewtondunn

text: The hourly Brexit countdown clock has just...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Missed in the melee last night - a blistering accusation from Emmanuel Macron. The EU has had to step in, as “British politicians are today unable to implement what the people asked”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The final mystery of the night solved: what did May eat in her windowless room while the EU27 dined on three courses without her? They took pity, and sent her servings to her on a silver service tray.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Even a long delay, a softer Brexit or a Customs Union, I asked May? She denied none of them: "What the Council has done is very clearly frame for people the choices that will be available to them”. So where are we now? Right back at the beginning of the week again (3/3)
author: tnewtondunn

text: We put all four choices to the PM, and the only one she ruled out was revocation. She also suggested she'd be bound by whatever decision the Commons comes up with a majority for if her deal falls, telling me: “I am very clear we will need to work with house how to proceed" (2/3)
author: tnewtondunn

text: This has been one crazy evening in Brussels. So what on earth are we left with? Donald Tusk said tonight: "The UK Government will still have a choice of a deal, no deal, a long extension or revoking Article 50" (1/3)
author: tnewtondunn

text: A terrible look.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I’m told by an EU official that there’s a proper battle royal under way among the EU27 over extension end date, it’s “lively in the room”. Some UK allies (Denmark) want it pushed back to June 30, others (France) want it earlier than May 22 #EUCO
author: tnewtondunn

text: Uh oh.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I'd missed that in all the excitement. Thanks Jill!
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here's something frightening/enlightening to do, depending on your disposition. Set up an alert for this account. You get an hourly countdown, on the hour, every hour.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thinking of you Isabel. Get well soon.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brussels Quote of the Day: When will you lose patience? Jean-Claude Juncker: "I didn’t even know I had this much patience" #EUCO
author: tnewtondunn

text: Hmm, I didn’t hear her say that...
author: tnewtondunn

text: ‘Elsewhere in the note, headed “top lines and Q&A” it says that if MPs reject the PM’s deal again, “MPs will have to decide how to proceed’. So May will not actually carry out a No Deal, but be bound by a Commons vote for a long delay?
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM holding a hastily arranged bilat with Emmanuel Macron in Brussels before summit starts. Appears France still playing hardball on any A50 extension #EUCO
author: tnewtondunn

text: Huge if true
author: tnewtondunn

text: On the Eurostar to the last ever EU summit for Britain after 45 years of them - my entire life. Or is it? (my bet: we’ll all be on the way back out to Brussels in 7 days time)
author: tnewtondunn

text: In Trump we trust? Good luck with that.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And this Labour MP said she could now vote for PM’s deal at 5pm today. May’s onslaught is backfiring.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Johnny Mercer calls for rule change to Tory leadership contests to stop stitch up and move on from Brexit - MPs should allow members to pick from 4 candidates
author: tnewtondunn

text: And from Brexiteers too;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cue the backlash;
author: tnewtondunn

text: The strongest part of PM's statement here - pitching herself as the public's warrior against Parliament. High risk, as will infuriate ERG, and has failed every time she's tried to brow beat before. Third time lucky?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Tusk lays down the gauntlet - says EU will only grant a short A50 extension if PM can pass her Brexit deal before next Friday.
author: tnewtondunn

text: A significant amount of Leavist Cabinet ministers are meeting the PM in No10 now (eg Gove, Fox, Leadsom, Hunt etc) - as many as 18, I'm told. Remainists (Chx, Clarke, Rudd, Perry) not invited. Are there two Cabinets now?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Least surprising decision of the day: John Bercow grants an emergency SO24 debate on A50 extension, and it will begin immediately.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Ian Blackford and now Anna Soubry petitioning the Speaker for the Commons to sit in emergency on Saturday (presumably for more time to enforce a lengthening of A50 extension).
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 also confirm PM will not ask for any extension to the transition period - will still end on Dec 31, 2020 if not extended/backstop entered. So that’s just 18 months to secure an FTA now.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Another school of Tory thought is UK will only leave EU by June 30 if she does agree to resign by then. Whichever it is, high chance Britain will soon be looking for a new PM
author: tnewtondunn

text: Despite May dropping multiple hints in #PMQs that she would resign if UK hasn’t left EU by June 30, No10 spokesman has just repeatedly refused to confirm that. Inconsistent? Her?
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM’s letter to Tusk. The solitary reason for an A50 extension to June 30? I need one more heave to pass my deal at MV3. That’s it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Top appointments
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here we go. The crisis is about to deepen considerably. Anna Soubry reveals Alison McGovern tabling an SO24 emergency debate, which will begin the process of Parliament attempting to take control of Brexit extension length from PM #r4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Senior minister: “My comment for today is: ‘Aaargh’”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Instantaneously. Thank you though.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Remainer Cabinet source: “This is the move that ensures she stays in No 10, avoiding decision. It will not work as a strategy for getting the Deal through. This is not what Parliament voted for last week”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: So what’s changed in 6 days? @DLidington is probably wondering that too.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Yes thank you!
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Brexit latest: Theresa May on verge of abandoning ultimatum to ERG for a long delay after bruising Cabinet revolt. Leaves her plan to avoid No Deal in tatters (1)
https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/8675155/theresa-may-brexit-delay-cabinet-revolt/ …
author: tnewtondunn

text: Ministers in open despair, with Govt's Brexit strategy in freefall. A Leave minister: “Nobody knows what the f*** is going on, or even who in No10 is gripping it. Maybe nobody is. The whole thing is a national humiliation on a scale we haven't seen in many, many decades” (4)
author: tnewtondunn

text: ERG draws up letter to PM of fresh demands for her to press on EU27 in Brussels on Thurs over Withdrawal Agreement - despite No10/EU saying negotiation closed (3)
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM's allies now expect her to apply for just one A50 extension of 3 months on Weds - but Remain ministers warn that will delight ERG, who will run down the clock for No Deal on June 30 (2)
author: tnewtondunn

text: The EU vice tightens. Barnier lays down the gauntlet: "My view is a longer extension needs to be linked to a new political event, a new process". In other words; if MV3 fails, UK must apply for a softer Brexit negotiation or 2nd EU ref - or it's No Deal.
author: tnewtondunn

text: He won't, as there are a myriad of workarounds... and everybody knew this yesterday too.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Will EU27 only sign off a provisional delay, dependent on “clarity” from the Commons on why next week? Yikes, squeaky bum time
author: tnewtondunn

text: Should you care about the Bercow row? No. It’s a massive red herring distraction, that serves pretty much everybody right now - especially, as it happens, No10, because it lets PM do this . A handy excuse for her, as she would have lost MV3 today or tomorrow.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks John, v kind
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sorry! Think of it as a biology lesson.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks David
author: tnewtondunn

text: Actually, I wasn’t. Neither am I a Tory, or a supporter of any party.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit latest: Theresa May drawing up letter to Donald Tusk to formally request one 9-12 month Brexit delay, but with an escape clause if Meaningful Vote is (ever) passed
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Tory Brexiteers threaten to go on "vote strike" and paralyse the Government if Theresa May delays Brexit by a year
author: tnewtondunn

text: Poor Brexit minister @KwasiKwarteng, now uncomfortably delivering a statement from the Despatch Box on how HMG will apply for a long Article 50 extension if MV3 falls - which he personally voted against last week too.
author: tnewtondunn

text: As if things weren't complicated enough... Speaker Bercow issues ruling to forbid any Meaningful Vote 3 if it's substantially the same proposition. Brexiteers and Labour delighted, Govt will be furious.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks Justine.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Et tu Guido? Sell out.
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 sets new deadline for MPs: unless it’s clear there is a majority for an MV3 when Parliament rises on Tuesday night, PM will go to Brussels on Thursday and apply for long A50 extension (that’s the last possible moment to table an MV motion for debate on Weds).
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sounds like Jacob Rees-Mogg is about to switch. To #LBC: “No deal is better than a bad deal, but a bad deal is better than remaining in the European Union, in the hierarchy of worst options”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Intriguing leadership calculation by Boris, when most thought he'd back the deal. While pleasing much of the membership, he makes it even harder to get down to the last two in the MPs' ballot (already tough). Perhaps he feels he can't jump until Raab does.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Can you ever see yourself telling PM her time’s up? Hammond: “The PM is focused on getting her deal through Parliament. She will always do what she feels is in the country’s best interests”. That’s very clearly not a no #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Hammond:”If the Prime Minister’s deal doesn’t pass this week, we’re going to have to have a very frank conversation with ourselves about what we do support”. Another threat to ERG - this is your last chance to avoid EEA/CU #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: An MV3 this week is “not definite”, Hammond says. Dependent on there being enough switchers for a majority for it, and Govt “not yet” there #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Three times, Philip Hammond refuses to rule out more money for NI in exchange for DUP’s votes for MV3 #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Nick votes for PM’s Brexit deal at every time of asking, and gets forced out. Boris doesn’t, and maximises his chance of being leader. Funny old business these days is politics.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And if Barclay goes, how can Cairns, Fox, Grayling, Leadsom, Mordaunt, Truss and Williamson stay on with any personal integrity intact, having also protested against the policy last night?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Barclay’s words here also directly contradict No10 last night (and @DLidington this morning) who insisted the whole Cabinet have agreed to back PM’s two delay plan, despite the free vote.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Looks like Steve Barclay will resign next week if the deal falls at MV3 and PM applies for a longer delay. He makes it clear he won’t support that... so she’ll need a 4th Brexit Secretary.
author: tnewtondunn

text: “It’s all over”. One pretty apocalyptic view
author: tnewtondunn

text: How brave of you to tweet defamatory rubbish anonymously. You’ve obviously never served.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And there was me thinking the Chief Whip serves the Prime Minister. How 2018 of me.
author: tnewtondunn

text: ...and: the Chief Whip Julian Smith abstained. His deputy Chris Pincher also voted against the PM, with most of the senior whips. Hard to think of a more insulting blow to May's authority.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Wow. A total of eight Cabinet ministers (Steve Barclay, Alun Cairns, Liam Fox, Chris Grayling, Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt, Lis Truss and Gavin Williamson) plus 188 Tory MPs in total voted against PM's motion to delay Brexit - close to two thirds of all her MPs.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Confirmed: Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay voted AGAINST the PM's motion he had just spoken from the Despatch Box in favour of to close the debate. Go figure.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I’m told Fox, Williamson and Barclay plus half the whips office is curently in the No Lobby, voting AGAINST their own PM’s motion.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Turns out May only kept control of the order paper with the votes of these 6 Labour and 4 independent MPs...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Get this: if one more Tory MP had voted with the rebels, it would have been a tie - and Speaker Bercow would have to cast a vote for the status quo... ie the Govt.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Wow. Very narrow escape for Govt: Benn amendment for Parliament to take control of Brexit defeated, by 312 v 314.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Labour split three ways on the 2nd referendum vote: 25 voted for, 18 voted against, the rest abstained. Very messy for Corbyn, who whipped for a no show.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit votes - TIG amendment to extend Article 50 long enough to hold a 2nd referendum defeated, 85 v 334, a majority of 249. Massive Labour no show.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I'm told the crucial vote coming up on Benn-Letwin (rebels seize control of the order paper) will be "a nail biter". Numbers extremely tight as Tory ministers now can't go missing after last night's shenanigans.
author: tnewtondunn

text: That's a cracking headline on your story...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Bernard Jenkin openly accuses Bercow of pro-Remain bias: “What are we to conclude from your own views on these matters?”
author: tnewtondunn

text: Bercow has refused select ERG's amendment to rule out a second referendum, despite having 127 signatures. Here comes a riot.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Now 127 signatures. Will Bercow risk a riot and refuse to select it?
author: tnewtondunn

text: The PM has called a political Cabinet for 1.30pm .
author: tnewtondunn

text: Asked whether the PM intends to do as @GeorgeFreemanMP asks and set a date to resign, PMOS: “That’s not something I’ve discussed with her, nor do I intend to”. Can you imagine the icey wind if he did?
author: tnewtondunn

text: In lobby briefing: No10 refused to call PM’s motion tonight a Government one - it can’t, because May too weak to whip it. The startling conclusion is therefore the Govt doesn’t currently have any collective policy on Brexit, at all.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Inspired, ⁦@paulwaugh⁩
author: tnewtondunn

text: Public calls from Remainer Tories for PM to make the ultimate sacrifice now too. This, from her former No10 policy chief:
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is leverage music to May’s ears.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Seething Brexiteer Tory MPs lining up on ERG’s WhatsApp group in their dozens to vote against Govt A50 motion tonight, and John McDonnell confirms to #r4Today Labour will amend it - leaving it no hope of passing. Then what?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Suggest you either produce evidence for that Adam, or delete it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Apologies, let me clarify Michael, I should have said the hardline members of the ERG. Some of your colleagues have privately said they would indeed do this.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Downing Street refusing to say whether ministers who abstained tonight will be sacked - only if they voted AGAINST Govt,
author: tnewtondunn

text: As many as 20 ministers abstained to break the 3 line whip, one of them says.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Govt loses its bid to throw out its own motion to stop No Deal being taken off the table permanently; by 321 v 278, a majority of 43 - defeat inflicted by Tory ministers abstaining. An extraordinary mess.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Veterans minister Tobias Ellwood is abstaining, against the Govt's 3 line whip.
author: tnewtondunn

text: It's "total carnage" in the division lobbies, one Tory MP says. Another: "Some who are not prepared to vote against the amended motion are just being allowed to go the pub".
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tory Brexiteer bid for a managed No Deal - the Malthouse Compromise - defeated by 374 v 164, a majority of 210.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Govt defeated - Commons demands No Deal is taken off the table permanently; 312 v 308, majority of 4. This puts May in a massive bind.
author: tnewtondunn

text: More than 50 MPs have signed the ERG's 'no second referendum' amendment so far. Labour's Caroline Flint and Gareth Snell agree to be lead signatories.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Govt whip carnage latest: No10 announce Malthouse amendment tonight will have a free vote (a climb down after Cabinet revolt), but Spelman’s will be whipped against.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here’s the text. Brexiteers think they face a tremendous battle persuading Bercow to accept it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I hear an interesting move is afoot by Tory/DUP/Labour Brexiteer MPs - tabling a joint amendment to rule out a 2nd Referendum in principle for Thursday’s voting. Plan is to spike People’s Vote’s guns early.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Spring Statement summary: Chancellor dangles a mammoth £26bn in front on MPs for tax cuts and departmental budget rises from the Autumn - but only if they endorse a Brexit deal. The biggest political bribe of all time.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Another extraordinary land grab from Hammond, in complete defiance of the PM beside him, as he calls on Commons to “map out a way forward for bringing a consensus” with tomorrow’s A50 vote.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Philip Hammond calls for Commons to “put aside our differences and seek a compromise in the national interest”; ie, a softer Brexit deal. This is pointedly not MV3, which is why PM has a face like thunder behind him.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Theresa May forced off the fence again to all but shoot down the Malthouse amendment, as she was expected to. Very unlikely to pass without a Govt whip for it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The Govt is in an unprecedented crisis that is worsening by the day, but Jeremy Corbyn’s waffley soundbite questions have done nothing to end it. Sharper opposition might have prevented the depth we’ve descended to #PMQs
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cabinet's spectacular dust up this morning over whipping tonight's No Deal amendments reveals the huge danger of giving free votes. Now the PM has let the genie out of the bottle on Brexit end game, she may never put it back in again. This is what happened to Cameron.
author: tnewtondunn

text: As if PM doesn’t have enough problems... serious divisions within Cabinet emerging tonight too. Remainer ministers will mount a fresh push tomorrow for her to forge a softer Brexit deal with Labour instead.
author: tnewtondunn

text: So where on earth does PM go from here? No10 repeatedly refused to take her deal off the table tonight - so it’s clear she’ll now go for a 3rd Meaningful Vote, but try to take out all other options first (eg No Deal tmrw). So get ready for 2 weeks of very bloody Commons warfare.
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is the PM's motion for tomorrow:
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM reveals all Tory MPs will have a free vote on tomorrow's No Deal motion, as it's "an issue of grave importance". She will urge the Commons to vote against one.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Break: Government loses 2nd Meaningful Vote on Brexit deal by 391 v 242, a majority of 149.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Quite a bit of feverish speculation mounting among Tory MPs on what PM will say at 7.15 after MV is lost - from an immediate A50 extension (possible) to her resignation (unlikely). A big moment. She has one shot at directing the chaos and staying in control.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Another switcher. Johnny Mercer changes his vote to back the deal. She needs a tidal wave not a trickle though.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Hubbie Philip May appears to agree. He’s in the public gallery watching her. I’ve only seen him do that twice before, at moments of maximum danger for her.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tory benches embarrassingly only half full for the PM’s speech, she’s losing her voice badly again, and it’s tipping it down outside. May’s Premiership has an end of days feel to it today.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here we go. Tory grandee Charles Walker demands PM calls a general election if she loses Meaningful Vote tonight: “She has to get a new mandate for the sake of the country. Needs must when the devil drives. We cannot go on trying to govern like this” #WATO
author: tnewtondunn

text: The ERG have spoken, and give the deal the thumbs down. Another big nail in its coffin.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cox admits to Hilary Benn that ECJ will still oversee the backstop arbitration committee after all. Another fart at a funeral for the ERG.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The decision for Brexiteer MPs now is a political one, not a legal one. They have less than seven hours to weigh up a massive amount of competing risks.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cox's verdict is out, and devastating for No10: Risk of being kept in the backstop is reduced, but remains unchanged if the EU is not found at fault.
author: tnewtondunn

text: It means: "I'm shitting with you, because I can".
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cox will come to the Commons at 1230.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Quote of the morning, Danish PM Lars Løkke Rasmussen: “It is difficult to give a helping hand to people who stand with both hands in their pockets” (ht @florianeder)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Nick Timothy’s gloomy verdict - hold your nose and back it. “As grotesquely flawed as it is, MPs who want to see Brexit through should vote for the deal. In a choice between certain death and probable death, it is better to stay alive.”
author: tnewtondunn

text:
What has May got?
1. An arbitration mechanism to escape the backstop - but no time limit.
2. Legally binding changes - but not ones she initially asked for.
3. An aspiration for Alternative Arrangements by December 2020 - but no hard start date.
Enough for all ERG? Unlikely.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Senior Tory MP suggests May will lose a no confidence vote in her Govt this week if she pulls the MV tomorrow - with his help?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Congrats Seb. Thoroughly deserved.
author: tnewtondunn

text: They might well. Everything for No10 from now onwards is high risk and messy.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Worth noting there are several ways May can make tomorrow’s MV provisional. One is to press ahead with it to fulfil her promise to the Commons, but accept a patsy backbench amendment to strap on Cox (pardon the expression). Another is to hold a second vote straight after (6)
author: tnewtondunn

text: So, Britain could effectively have a twin track Government for the next 10 days - May’s, and Cooper/Letwin’s in the wings - with the EU Council to pick between them, over a late night dinner in Brussels on Thursday week, just 7 days before Brexit. What a cliffhanger (5)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Will Letwin/Cooper/Boles accept another 10 day can kick? No. Expect them to amend tomorrow’s vote to enforce an A50 extension vote on Weds or Thurs, whether PM wins or loses. But whatever the rebels demand, nothing can be signed off by the EU Council until it meets next week (4)
author: tnewtondunn

text: All this, I’m told, was discussed by the PM with Jean-Claude Juncker last night. No10 consider it a win that Juncker even agreed to keep technical negotiations going between officials by the end of the call, so bad is the impasse now (3)
author: tnewtondunn

text: If she can produce a Commons majority for any detailed deal on the backstop (not just the Brady fudge), then the EU just might buckle and concede to it at the last minute at next week’s EU Council on March 21/22 (2)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit latest: PM meeting with senior aides in No10 now to plot a way through this week’s carnage. I’m told it’s most likely she will decide to change tomorrow’s vote from a meaningful one to a provisional one - ie her deal, plus Cox’s changes (1)
author: tnewtondunn

text: We needed that after the FA Cup tbh
author: tnewtondunn

text: Paris flattered you from your performance just then.  4th place!
author: tnewtondunn

text: Yes. AFC 2-MUFC 0 #COYG
author: tnewtondunn

text: And delivers music to the EU’s ears, who’d love to reverse Brexit. Unsure this is the best negotiating tactic in Brussels. (Hunt’s 3 steps; 1. Vote down deal, 2. Win delay, 3. 2nd EU ref).
author: tnewtondunn

text: Jeremy Hunt calls for “realism” in Brussels and Westminster to get PM’s deal over the line. Good luck with that. #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: John McDonnell says a Brexit delay should be for “as long as necessary”. Emily Thornberry says for no more than 3 months. Labour urgently need to sort of their line on this #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: David Davis dismisses any Theresa May offer to stand down to break the Brexit impasse: “No, no, that won’t get the deal through”. ERG are split on this - Borisites would go for it, Bakerites wouldn’t #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: David Davis says he “might” vote for PM’s deal if Geoffrey Cox can win an independent arbitration mechanism. A shard of hope for No10, though too late for this week #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Jeremy Hunt steps up leadership bid with secret breakfasts with Cabinet ministers - now being seen by Tory MPs as frontrunner to replace May
author: tnewtondunn

text: . Talks going well I see.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Missed this. An extraordinary interview on multiple fronts, not least because these two have had some spectacular live dust ups. Bravo @KayBurley and @RhonddaBryant.
author: tnewtondunn

text: May's best speech line is also her riskiest - an attempt to isolate hardline Brexiteers from the voters: "Brexit does not belong to MPs in Parliament, it belongs to the whole country. Everyone now wants to get it done".
author: tnewtondunn

text: May accuses Corbyn of running away from Brexit talks with her again, offering No10 only one hour in the last 5 weeks "despite multiple requests from my office".
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM implores EU leaders for "just one more push" to get the backstop over the line. A lot more conciliatory than the overnight blame game language.
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 confirms not all 600 SIs needed for No Deal will be passed by March 29: “We are prioritising the ones that are important. Obviously the timetable is short”. This is a big admission.
author: tnewtondunn

text: George Eustice, writing for ⁦@ConHome⁩ today, reveals not all the Govt’s 600 No Deal SIs will be passed by March 29 now (but argues that doesn’t necessarily matter)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Why Cox’s Codpiece has car crashed. Point 9 in Nick’s excellent thread nails it
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Brexit latest: 
1. Backstop talks still deadlocked, Cox cancels Brussels trip on Friday
2. No10 sources admits situation “bleak”, Tuesday’s vote may happen without new deal
3. May tells EU chiefs Brexit deal will be voted down unless they climb down
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Tory chiefs fear they could  lose 1,000 councillors in a local elections meltdown, sealing Theresa May’s fate in No10
author: tnewtondunn

text: Govt announces that DexEU Permanent Secretary Philip Rycroft is retiring "at the end of this month" - ie, last day in the office March 29. What an extraordinary time to lose its top mandarin.
author: tnewtondunn

text: For a No Deal Brexit to work, you need a Trade Bill. The current one has a CU slapped onto it, and I can’t see the Commons overturning that on March 30 if we leave without a deal. Can you? That’s my point.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Meanwhile in London, ministers begin to panic and predict “a party meltdown nationwide” if PM's deal falls next week. Brexiteer minister: "If we lose on Tuesday, absolutely everything is going to be shit".
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit latest - backstop talks on verge of collapse. Brussels meeting on Thursday to discuss whether it’s even worth holding any further negotiations, as two sides so far apart (with @nick_gutteridge)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Rising star Tory MP Johnny Mercer calls on Theresa May and her ageing Cabinet to stand aside: "It’s time for a new generation to take over and govern differently”.

text: Latest - Lords defeat the Government to enforce a customs union with the EU as part of any Brexit deal, by 207 v 141. A massive new headache for No10. Unclear whether PM will still have the votes to overturn the Trade Bill amendment in the Commons.

text: And this is the vehicle which the Commons could use to enforce a Customs Union. Trade Bill back in the Lords tomorrow.  Amendment expected to win.

text: Excl: Chief Whip told Cabinet that Parliament will push Britain into a permanent customs union with EU if PM’s Brexit deal is voted down next week

text: Amy Winehouse’s mother Jane, on winning a #CSJAwards for #AmysPlace addiction recovery house for young women: “When we lost Amy in 2011, it felt like our family had ended. We realised human interaction was the cure”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Honoured to have presented a #CSJAwards tonight to the brilliant @SafeFamiliesUK, who give a family to kids in need so they don’t have to join the 10,000 a year going into care.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Follow #CSJAwards to see who wins one of the @csjthinktank’s coveted gongs to honour the work of brilliant poverty-fighting charities across the country. Ceremony starting now (I was a judge)

text: Jeremy Hunt opens the door to a free vote for Tory MPs next week on No Deal or extending A50, as “something for the Government and Prime Minister to make a decision on”. Can it really not to come to a single view on something that important?

text: Brexiteers and eurocrats accuse Theresa May of trying to bounce them into a last minute new Brexit deal. ERG demand 48 hours before Commons debate starts to scrutinise Cox backstop.

text: Excl: Ministers drawing up a new Espionage Bill to catch Russian spies - but delayed until 2020 because of Parliament logjam
author: tnewtondunn

text: To lose one Dimbleby is unfortunate, but to lose two... @dimbleby_jd's retirement from #bbcaq is a real sadness. A superb questioner, as well kind and funny behind the scenes.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The reality for May's minority government today is it's finding it ever harder to pass any legislation at all, as authority continues to seep away from No10. This cannot really go on for much longer.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The Financial Services Bill is the 1st of 6 bills that Govt must pass (thru both houses) by March 29 to make No Deal possible. It was due to leave Commons tonight. So yet another Brexit timetabling disaster.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Extraordinary stats from ⁦@ONS⁩ today on the digitally left behind - 5 million didn’t use the internet at all in UK last year; 1 in 8 in North East, 1 in 7 in N Ireland.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Key target Ruth Smeeth tells #WestmimsterHour that PM’s £1.6bn town renewal fund to win Labour MPs’ votes for her Brexit deal is “an extraordinarily pathetic sum of money” and “a waste of time”. Oh.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Uh oh. Backs up the gloomy noises over little progress from within No10/DexEU this week . Realistically, PM has 7 days left to come up with something. Has to give MPs at least the weekend to consider before March 12 Meaningful Vote.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Intriguing suggestion from @Simonhartmp today to (London Playbook) that PM would have to offer a free vote on any A50 extension. Some Brexiteer ministers agree. One tells me: “Trying to whip votes after the deal is defeated will be impossible without splitting the whole party”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Ministers crackdown on snobbish landlords who refuse to let their properties to poorer workers on housing benefit
author: tnewtondunn

text: Quite a few Tory MPs have just shouted their opposition to the Cooper amendment, enshrining PM's A50 extension promise - which the Govt is now whipping for. So we have a new Brexiteer rebellion under way...

text: Lidington forced to give more ground to Remainer rebels: agrees to @NickBoles' insistence that Commons must have a veto on the length of any A50 extension. Will the house be able to approve whatever final extension length is agreed? “The answer is yes”.

text: First hurdle successfully jumped by Govt  - Oliver Letwin declares he's satisfied with Lidington's repetition of PM's A50 promise yesterday, and says no need to move Amendment C now.
author: tnewtondunn

author: tnewtondunn

text: The battle today is over C and F. Remainer rebels want HMG to back F, so the Commons can the promise for an A50 extension vote in concrete. If it doesn't, they are threatening to push C, to seize control of Brexit timetable. So significant risk still for HMG today.

text: Rudd, Gauke, Clark and Perry were silent when the PM announced it, but appeared to have accepted the offer and will end their rebellion for now. The angriest with them was Andrea Leadsom, who accused the quartet of "betrayal" (2)

text: 3. PM not ruling out No Deal next month willingly. She’s been convinced that it’s now the only way she can stop Remain ministers passing Cooper-Letwin, which is viewed in No10 as “catastrophic”.

text: 2. Aides are split over whether PM should make the major concession directly when she addresses the Commons after Cabinet, or just agree to be bound by a future vote for it (on March 12).
author: tnewtondunn

text: The crucial caveats: 1. To avoid total Brexiteer meltdown, PM still wants to keep the option of No Deal alive for later in the year after any delay kicks in.

author: tnewtondunn

text: It’s clearly not possible to ask Parliament to ratify a treaty before the EU formally agrees it, on March 22. Nor will it be poss to ratify it in the 4 sitting days before March 29 after that. But admitting to that means conceding a technical extension, which is now inevitable.
author: tnewtondunn

text: An extraordinary proposition from Theresa May to achieve Brexit on time - says she could try to pass a Withdrawal Agreement Bill through the Commons BEFORE the EU27 even formally sign off a new deal on March 22: “It is possible to do it either way”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: It appears even Angela Merkel thinks Theresa May could extend Article 50. In their breakfast bilat in Sharm El-Sheikh, she asked the PM if the Telegraph p1 story about a 2 month extension was true. PM denied it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Philip Hammond also pushing hard for a Brexit delay behind the scenes - he delivered the Rudd/Gauke/Clark article to PM’s Chief of Staff Gavin Barwell before it was published last week.
author: tnewtondunn

text: One minister planning to vote for Cooper-Letwin: “The PM likes baking and understands its analogies. It’s not enough to have the ingredients on the sideboard, they need to be raising in the oven”.

author: tnewtondunn

text: 2. She is imploring Remain rebels to give her two more weeks to get a better deal. Announces a new Meaningful Vote on it will be held by March 12 (when there will be just 17 days to go until Brexit ).

text: Government's working majority with the DUP now reduced to 8. @TheIndGroup now the 5th largest party in the Commons.

text: A pro-Leave Tory minister told me this morning that Wollaston and Allen have always been independent spirits, selected via primaries, but Soubry's departure is a serious blow to the party. A prominent One Nation moderate, and former Cabinet level minister.

text: The #Gangof7 is actually 10, if Frank Field, John Woodcock and Ivan Lewis (all already sitting as independents) join them. That makes them the Commons’ 5th equal largest group, with the DUP. Five more, and they overtake the Lib Dems.

text: The key point. If no more than 1 or 2 Remainer ministers are prepared to break the whip on Thursday, there is no leverage.

text: Andrea Leadsom reveals 411 of the 600 SIs needed for Brexit now laid, so still 189 to go in the 6 weeks left. I’m told this is the real reason why recess was scrapped next week.
author: tnewtondunn

text: But the flaw is very few of them are committed to resigning yet if No10 refuses. One who is very likely to though is Industry Minister Richard Harrington, who has told friends it’s now “a matter of personal credibility” for him.
author: tnewtondunn

text: 25 anti-no deal ministers met secretly in the Commons this afternoon to agree the new demand, put together by Sir Oliver Letwin. Deal to be offered to No10 = Cooper/Boles amendment won’t be tabled this week if PM agrees.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Tory Remainer ministers to demand PM grants Parliamentary time to Cooper/Boles if still no deal after Feb 27 as their price to support her on Thursday

text: There isn’t a Tory MP in Parliament who believes this. Here are some of the reasons why; https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/brexit/8257029/ …

Excl: Theresa May preparing to resign as PM this summer so she can influence who succeeds her, Cabinet ministers believe

text: No10: PM will deliver update to Commons on Brexit tomorrow, instead of Wednesday. Why? No reason given, but looks like PM advised to calm Remainers’ fears of chaos earlier not later.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Appalling new monthly figures for the economy in December from @ONS: every single sector contracted. Growing Brexit stagnation as everyone sits on their money for what next... piles yet more pressure on No10 to get a deal.
author: tnewtondunn

text: ...but then goes on to pay huge lip service to the Malthouse Compromise, calling it “very exciting”. He’s riding the wonky supermarket trolley this morning.

author: tnewtondunn

text: James Brokenshire reveals a new amendable Commons vote on PM’s Brexit plan by February 27 if still no deal by then. Tory MPs now being asked to kick can further down the road for the whole month #Marr

author: tnewtondunn

text: Careful Simon, that's libellous. Smear is to impute dishonesty.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Not disputed Henry. Those few aspirations were (eventually) articulated, but the plan to deliver them was wholly absent, purposely.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Caveat 2 - consigning them to hell is a tad strong. Two and half years in purgatory is a more fitting punishment. Here endeth the thread (7)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Two caveats: 1. some more honourable leavers, who knew a bit more about the EU, did try to argue on detail (eg @DanielJHannan or @chhcalling) but they received little attention from voters/us the media at the time (6)
author: tnewtondunn

text: That, or a fair amount of it, could have been avoided if @BorisJohnson and others had argued on detail rather than sentiment, and we may well not be in this mess now (5)
author: tnewtondunn

text: The downside is, as we all now know, Britain has spent the subsequent 2 and a half years tearing itself apart over exactly what the 17.4m who voted for Brexit want from it (4)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Why? So that they wouldn't fall into Alex Salmond's trap during the #indyref of getting killed on the detail. @matthew_elliott confirmed this at the time, and it was a masterful strategy that worked (3)
author: tnewtondunn

text: The Leave campaign took the conscious decision at the start of the #EUref campaign in 2016 to keep both their definition of Brexit and any plan to deliver it vague (2)
author: tnewtondunn

text: An unpopular view in Westminster, but @eucopresident is right - and all good Brexiteers (as well as Remainers) should agree with him. Here's why... (1)

text: Hampton Court
author: tnewtondunn

author: tnewtondunn

text: "Nobody". This tweet confirms the EU wants to do nothing until after the Feb 14 vote, which will reveal whether the PM still has a workable majority for her Plan C.

text: Voting down Theresa May’s deal again will mean an Article 50 extension, David Gauke warns ERG: “If we are to leave on March 29, MPs need to be backing a deal in short order” #r4today

text: Javid flogging alternative arrangements for a backstop change hard, over the other two options - time limit and exit mechanism. Designed to please the ERG, but annoy No10. Notable new Cabinet slit emerging, after Clark trashed it last week #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sajid Javid concedes there will be “a change in capability” over security under no deal, that could not mean “like for like”. Won’t deny this means the country will be less safe #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Whereas I’m gutted to miss State of the Union...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Extending A50 by 2 years is surely preferable to a no change rule-taker transition period. This is so sensible that it has zero chance of uniting Tory MPs.

author: tnewtondunn

text: But the good news is we are getting ‘a general debate on sport in the UK’ on Monday. Phew.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Extraordinary. No Govt bills before the Commons at all next week, on #Brexit or anything else. Total paralysis confirmed.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Commons half term recess cancelled because of the Brexit crisis. You read it here by @steve_hawkes 1st;

text: It’s factual! A committee chair, as well as a gallant gentleman.

text: Desperation seeping in. Senior backbencher pleas for his weekends and holidays to be ripped up to sort out #Brexit.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Jeremy Hunt says “a technical extension” of Article 50 may be needed if a new EU deal can’t be legislated for quickly. Most senior Govt minister yet to admit what everybody privately admits - Brexit is going to be delayed #r4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: May digs in for long Mexican stand off with EU - won’t decide on Brexit backstop requests until next week (despite only having 14 days to win them). Close ally: “There’s no point in going to Brussels until she can get a fair hearing”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: “Some of the ERG are now saying their vote means nothing and that whatever changes she gets, they won’t vote for the amended deal. Who knew??”... senior Tory minister. The truce is over.

text: Good read out. Meanwhile, tick tock.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Greg Clark also describes empty shelves in supermarkets under no deal as “fact” to @GuardianAnushka. But says KFC running out of chickens is “fake news” #Peston
author: tnewtondunn

text: Uh oh. Business Secretary Greg Clark attacks the 'Malthouse Compromise' plan as not feasible. Having studied max fac last year, says: "I can't see that those technical possibilities are there yet" #Peston
author: tnewtondunn

text: Trouble at mill - the love in was never going to last. No10 say there is "no change" to PM's negotiating team, and Falconer and Braithwaite are not being invited onto it. ERG are furious, and insist this was promised to them yesterday by Gavin Barwell.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Quite interestingly, May has had several opportunities in #PMQs now to say No Deal is still something she is prepared to do in extremis, post Spelman-Dromey, but pointedly hasn’t.
author: tnewtondunn

text: A lot of arrows fired by Corbyn at the Brexit bullseye. Some came close, but none on target. The killer Q he failed to ask is does PM agree with Caroline Spelman that her no deal vote is “morally binding?” #PMQs
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay unable to say precisely what changes PM will ask for to the backstop, despite being asked 5 times by @bbcnickrobinson on #r4today. No10 are no further on from yesterday’s fug.
author: tnewtondunn

text: That will make two of you then Stew
author: tnewtondunn

text: eh? reporting the facts.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: May’s capitulation to hardline Brexiteer demands was total - including a shake up of her negotiating team. Gavin Barwell promised it will now include UK’s rep to WTO Julian Braithwaite and DIT’s chief negotiator Crawford Falconer;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tremendous. So much hot air in the Commons tonight that the fire brigade got called.
author: tnewtondunn

text: What do tonight's votes mean? May has won a couple more weeks, but not a Brexiteer Commons majority that will pass a deal that the EU is prepared to offer (yet, or ever). Likelihood still is we'll do this all over again on Valentine's Day.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Govt wins Brady amendment by 317 v 301. Gives PM a mandate to ask the EU to renegotiate the backstop.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Govt loses motion to insist Britain doesn't leave the EU without a deal, by 318 v 310. Non-binding, but the will of the House Commons.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Govt defeats Cooper/Boles by 321 v 298. Attempt to delay Brexit if there is no deal by Feb 26.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Govt defeat Grieve amendment by 321 v 301. First attempt by Commons to seize back control of Brexit.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Bad news for Cooper/Boles. I'm told around 30 Labour MPs will either abstain or vote against it, some on the frontbench. Will make the vote v tight.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Borrow away!
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 says PM considering three ways to ask the EU to change the Withdrawal Agreement: Malthouse, a backstop time limit or a unilateral exit from it. Won’t say when/how PM will decide between the 3. Today’s voting won’t clarify that either. Still confused in Brussels? We are.
author: tnewtondunn

text: So to sum up the PM's speech: she is now asking the Commons to rip up the deal she agreed with the EU, change the backstop she said was unchangeable, and has given herself just 14 days to talk the EU27 round. She sure likes a challenge.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tick 3: PM calls the Malthouse Compromise (Plan C) "a serious proposal that we're engaging with sincerely and positively". That should be enough to get @SteveBakerHW and @Jacob_Rees_Mogg on side too.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tick 2: PM promises to ask the EU for "a significant and legally binding change to the Withdrawal Agreement... it will involve reopening the WA". That gets the DUP and a lot of the ERG on side.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Three times, the PM refuses to rule out asking for an Article 50 extension to delay Brexit. Again.
author: tnewtondunn

text: That's one vote the PM seems to have lost - independent MP Lady Hermon calls Brady amendment wording 'nebulous', and tells her it won't work.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tick 1: PM agrees to a vote over no deal on Feb 14 if there is still no deal agreed. A Valentine's Day massacre, to persuade Remain ministers not to resign tonight.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Justice minister Rory Stewart concedes the Malthouse Compromise (Plan C) could delay Brexit, as it might need “a few days extension for a technical agreement” #PoliticsLive
author: tnewtondunn

text: It will sell.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I’m told the Plan C plotters asked PM yesterday to include it as an option in a Govt amendment to today’s vote. May refused, saying she needed time to think about it. Plotters now want her to give Plan C an enthusiastic mention at Despatch Box.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
So Plan C appears to be a Max Fac backstop a year later, or a no deal-deal if not. Some hurdles;
1. EU refuses to accept Max Fac, saying the technology doesn’t exist
2. Ditto a no deal-deal, as they won’t get the full £39bn
3. If Cooper/Boles passes, why should EU bother with it
author: tnewtondunn

text: Nicky Morgan says Plan C plotters had hoped it would be proposed by Govt in an amendment today. So sounds like No10 have already knocked it back #r4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Industry minister Richard Harrington demands hard promise from PM for a 2nd meaningful vote in two weeks time or he’ll vote for Cooper tonight - and be forced to resign #r4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks Bill
author: tnewtondunn

text: One day! V kind, thank you
author: tnewtondunn

text: On top of the ERG’s refuseniks, there could also be as many as 10 or so Tory Remainers rebelling. Reality is PM needs every single tiny thing to go her way tomorrow to stand a small chance.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Can the PM still get a majority and keep her deal alive? Tory whips say ERG rebels down to “about 20 diehards", ERG say closer to 40. Both would make it very hard, as still only a handful of Labour MPs willing to help.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The DUP will keep No10 sweating overnight. Its 10 MPs will meet tomorrow at 9.30am to decide whether to vote for the Brady amendment, and what their terms will be for doing that.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Boris appears to have had quite a ding dong with PM in the room. Kept yelling at her, “what do YOU want to do Prime Minister”, while she would only reply she’ll continue to “battle away”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Break: PM has just told all Tory MPs Govt will accept Brady amendment and whip for it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 not giving up on Brady yet, despite ERG’s defiance. I’m told John Baron and Andrew Murrison have just been persuaded to withdraw their amendments to give Brady a better chance of getting picked by Bercow.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I hear PM has summoned all Tory MPs to a special meeting at 5pm today in the Boothroyd Room. Will issue a final plea for unity ahead of tomorrow.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The excellent @jillongovt rang a former clerk, who told her the only way HMG can be sure of having any amendment voted on - theirs or another - is for HMG to amend their own motion to include it by tonight. Bercow doesn’t have to call any amendment.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The unity love-in is over. Tory MP calls ERG sorts "hardline Brexit ultras", equating them to Millwall hooligans.

text: Story here;

text: Hancock says he’s “sympathetic” to Graham Brady for searching for Tory unity. Warmest words yet from Govt about backing an amendment to remove the current backstop (as we revealed yesterday) #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Matt Hancock immediately refutes @simoncoveney and suggests he’s not serious about refusing to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement: “That’s a negotiating position that the Irish are taking” #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: And if the EU26 rat on Dublin, MEPs won’t, Coveney insists: “The European Parliament will not ratify a Withdrawal Agreement without a backstop in it. It’s as simple as that” #Marr

text:
“Ireland will insist on the United Kingdom keeping its word”. 
So no budging at all, no matter what amendment passes. But, Coveney can only say he “thinks” the EU27 shares his view. Not knows. #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Simon Coveney: “We have already agreed to compromises. The backstop is part of a balanced package that isn’t going to change”. Movement only possible on Political Declaration not Withdrawal Agreement, he adds #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Yvette Cooper says her revised bill to ask for a Brexit delay will also say for how long - as little as 3 months possible (but also 9 months, a year, etc). Decision for MPs on Feb 26 #Marr

text: Angela Rayner again being impressively honest and direct with @SophyRidgeSky. She opposes a 2nd referendum but says she’d still vote Remain during it. Still can’t help thinking she’ll lead Labour one day.

text: It certainly is! Thanks

text: One reason only: it keeps PM's deal alive... just, and probably gets her back around the Brussels table. Also, moderate allies point out how loosely worded the Brady amendment actually is (see Thurs eve tweet for hard copy), eg dump THE backstop, not A backstop.

text: Not to get a majority on Tuesday. Whether a majority for that is of any use is another matter.

text: One small problem with JRM's plan to prorogue Parliament and ensure a hard Brexit on March 29 - you'd have to suspend it forever. The moment MPs are allowed back, they'd amend the first Act in front of them to enforce a deal with the EU.

text: Intriguing shift in EU’s position on extending Article 50 from Barnier today. The 27 probably will, and no longer just for a democratic moment - but only if the Commons can demonstrate a clear (not a wafer thin) majority for a plan.

text: Is no deal better than a delayed deal? Liam Fox refutes, to insist the choice is no deal or no Brexit. That’s the problem with British politics today - nobody will even agree on the question #r4today

2. Dozens of Remain Tory ministers no longer have to resign to vote for it (now it’s a sure thing), and Theresa limps on

text:

text: Groundhog May latest: I'm told not to expect much from PM's statement, apart from a rough affirmation of Plan A with the need for "changes". No10 sorts think it's too early to show her hand. That will come on Jan 28/29 when HMG decides what friendly amendments to accept.

text: A shard of hope for PM now with EU disunity breaking out, or will this just overinflate Tory backbench expectations again? Probably both.

text: Yes, but but but... Merkel wants “compromise” too. Has told May that, and she also said on Saturday: “We have a responsibility to pursue this separation process responsibly so that in 50 years, people won’t shake their heads and say ‘Why weren’t they able to find a compromise?'”

text: I hear the PM just told Cabinet she will push on with her Brexit deal, no matter the size of tonight's defeat, as "it’s the only option". A big push from Rudd/Clark/Gauke/Perry to open talks with moderate Labour MPs, but rejected by Hunt/Javid/Fox/Lewis/Truss/Williamson.

text: All it is now is a simple organisational tool, to pressurise and set timings for briefings etc for the media. It’s a trade body, without which the media would have less leverage on Govt. So no, not really. Anyone journalist with a Parliamentary pass is welcome.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Whatever its oddities in the past, the Lobby now exists entirely to facilitate the flow of information from Govt/Opposition to the media. Any suggestion otherwise it’s the usual conspiracy theory bunkum.
author: tnewtondunn

text: What I suspect you have was written in 1982. We rewrote the ‘rules’ (in reality just a v short code of conduct) in 2017 to make it clear the secrecy and elitism of 30 years ago has long since disappeared and we are now wholly transparent. We serve our readers now, nobody else.

text: Excl: Senior Tories to try to persuade Theresa May to resign next Spring as only way to break Brexit deadlock;
