text: England manager Gareth Southgate: “The only real heroes are on your teams, not on ours” #Millies18
author: tnewtondunn

text: Nope, no idea what you're talking about.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Whatever @KayBurley is paid, and I'm sure it's generous, it's not enough to have to take numbskulls hurling bovine abuse at you non-stop for the past 3 weeks.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Fight;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Spot on from ⁦@paulwaugh⁩ here. I’ve asked the PM twice now to categorically rule out holding a 2nd referendum on her watch, that she says would be so wrong - twice she refused to.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Uh oh. May suggests she could stay on as PM for 3 more years. 
Will you go after Brexit? “No. People try to talk about dates. What I’m clear about is the next general election is in 2022, and I think it is right that another party leader takes us into that general election”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Fascinating to see the big US pick up of May's confidence saga. It's almost unheard of for domestic British politics to make the p1s of America's 4 biggest papers.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I don’t buy the payroll v backbenchers line. I suspect quite a few in Govt voted against her to try to fast track their careers.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Steve Barclay: “The Prime Minister now has the time to have discussions with European colleagues” #BBCR4today. Clear now that No10's new strategy is to push a deal vote as late as possible (Jan 20?) to ratchet up max pressure on Tory rebels/DUP to fold.
author: tnewtondunn

text: “I don’t see how we put the pieces of the jigsaw back together again. The blood is too bad, the polarities too extreme. It is no longer a functioning party that anyone is able to lead, let alone Theresa,” a Cabinet minister.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And finally: this man told me earlier that we’re in this political pickle because “Parliament has turned its back on Jesus”. Funnily enough, he didn’t feel at all out of place today.
author: tnewtondunn

text: A split now emerging between Tory Brexit rebels on how to handle the result. Compare Crispin Blunt's concession below with Jacob Rees-Mogg's: "Under all constitutional norms, she ought to go and see the Queen urgently and resign".
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 points out that 200 is 1 more vote than May got in the final ballot of the 2016 leadership election (199 out of 331, 60%). So in a way, nothing has changed.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Result's significance: not to even to carry two thirds of her MPs' support (63%) is a blow. She limps on, but wounded.
author: tnewtondunn

text: For PM: 200. Against: 117.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Theresa May wins confidence vote in her Tory leadership.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Lee Rowley: “Stamina is not a policy Prime Minister”. Ouch.
author: tnewtondunn

text: An ERG Tory asked PM, “What is your longterm intention after March?” This she ducked.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tory MP says Theresa May has just told them she will resign as PM before the next general election. Some Ministers reported to be in tears inside the committee room.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The PM has entered Committee Room 14 to address Tory MPs. Whips bang loudly in support on the doors, largely for for the benefit of journalists outside.
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM’s spokesman confirms Sir Graham Brady rang her at 11pm last night (phew... for some of us reporting letters not in before then!)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: PM’s spokesman signals for 1st time she will stand down before 2022 if she wins confidence vote tonight: “This vote isn’t about who leads the party into the next election”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I suspect Jeremy Corbyn has just pushed a few more wavering Tory MPs into May’s voting column. Only question 1 out of 6 made her sweat. The technical term: putting one up your own chuff #PMQs
author: tnewtondunn

text: Philip May is in the Commons gallery to watch his wife’s #PMQs. I have never seen him here before. Presumably because he thinks there’s a chance it could be her last.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Interesting view from one senior Tory eurosceptic: the confidence vote will badly backfire on the ERG. May will win, and be then forced to ally with Labour to join a Customs Union.
author: tnewtondunn

text: ...after, as we revealed on Monday, having spent weeks privately pushing for Sajid to replace Theresa May. That’s politics folks. (2)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sajid Javid’s PPS Simon Hoare tells @adamboultonSKY: “Some of my colleagues have forgotten to take their meds in the last 24 hours, or have taken leave of their senses”... (1)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Justice Sec David Gauke: “If she loses tonight, there would clearly have to be a delay to Article 50. That is simply a matter of fact”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brady reveals he spoke to PM late last night to confirm threshold had been reached @BBCr4today. Owen Paterson letter sent them appears to have been the 48th.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sir Graham Brady’s WhatsApp message to all Tory MPs just sent... “Events have moved very quickly overnight”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I’m Chopper Harris.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thank you (but I’m not right wing, left wing or any wing tbh)
author: tnewtondunn

text: 12lbs in 2 weeks?
author: tnewtondunn

text: On the way to @SkyNews for the paper reviews with @annabotting and @ayeshahazarika, where we will try hard (but probably fail) not to fuel the renewed frenzy about who has how many letters.
author: tnewtondunn

text: , with knobs on.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Senior No10 figure: "If the letters are in, nobody has told us".
author: tnewtondunn

text: Latest: friends of Graham Brady STILL say he has no plans to make a statement about a confidence vote on PM's leadership. Health warning: this could change at any time, but as of right now, the 48 letters appear not yet in.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Friends of Graham Brady say he is not yet in possession of 48 letters. Just under 8 hours left of this day to go though.
author: tnewtondunn

text: “When sorrows come, they come not single spies, but in battalions”...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Smutty headline of the year.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Many congratulations @Laura_K_Hughes, hugely deserved.
author: tnewtondunn

text: May wins a miniature fig leaf from Tusk. He agrees to an EU summit discussion on the deal to try to help her, but at same times refuses to reopen the backstop.
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM just made it clear the meaningful vote may not be tabled again until January 21. That’s a further 6 week delay, on a timetable that is already painfully tight to deliver all Brexit legislation in time for March 29. A50 extension ever more likely now.
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM will also say the meaningful vote will be suspended, indefinitely, until that happens. So, could well be not vote until after Xmas. Even if May succeeds, will it be enough to win over the DUP and ERG? (2)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Latest: I am told the PM will tell MPs she will not dump the backstop or reopen the Withdrawal Agreement, but instead seek legal assurances from the EU that it will not last indefinitely (1)
author: tnewtondunn

text: And then 2nd from @matt_dathan;
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Meaningful vote pulled - you read it here 1st;
https://twitter.com/tnewtondunn/status/1067545728384413697 … …
author: tnewtondunn

text: Meaningful Vote is off, Commons business being urgently rescheduled this afternoon. A spectacular mess.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Another Tory MP @SMcPartland withdrew his support for deal this morning...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Will @GeorgeFreemanMP be the last Tory MP to pull his support for the deal, before the deal itself is pulled?
author: tnewtondunn

text: As of 11am, No10 has just insisted the vote is still going ahead and the Withdrawal Agreement cannot be reopened. Simon Coveney also confirms the latter. So was the PM rebuffed in whatever she asked of EU leaders? (2)
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM's secret calls to EU leaders over the weekend were quite extensive: Merkel on Saturday afternoon, Rutte in the evening, Tusk and Juncker on Sunday morning, Varadkar the afternoon. (1)
author: tnewtondunn

text: The PM has called together all her senior aides for a meeting on the Meaningful Vote in No10 now. A decision on whether to pull it appears imminent.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Michael Gove is the latest senior Tory to refuse to rule himself out of a leadership run: “It’s extreeeeemely unlikely I’ll ever be in that position” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Michael Gove: “The vote is going ahead. I’m certainly not going to filibuster” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: “The revocation must be done following a democratic porcess”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Missed this last week. Whatever you think of the deal, that’s some oratory.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Meanwhile who do actual voters prefer? None of them, but Boris is no longer the electoral gold dust Tory associations still think he is, @YouGov find...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Former defence chief Lord Richards calls for amnesty for all IRA killers as well as Army veterans as only way to end 'witch hunt'.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Another senior Tory MP: “He told me that Theresa’s Brexit deal is s***, she’ll be forced out when it falls, and he is then going to declare immediately”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Sajid Javid to launch immediate leadership contest this week if May is forced from power. Cabinet minister: “Sajid is tapping us up. He is very direct”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And the fact that No10 is still ludicrously pretending neither call has happened is a sign that success for May is far from guaranteed.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Now why would Theresa May have done that today?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Painful stony silence at the end of Boris's #Marr interview as credits roll. He refuses small talk after accusing @AndrewMarr9 of “reducing the debate to relative trivialities" by asking about his leadership intentions.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Boris describes accusation he has already offered Cabinet jobs if he becomes PM as "nonsense", but refuses to rule out challenging Theresa May #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay won't rule out PM going back to Brussels to reopen the negotiation this week, but says it would be high risk as French/Spanish could also ask for more: “The risk for those who simply say go back, well that isn’t a one way street” #Marr
author: tnewtondunn

text: Esther McVey reveals to @SophyRidgeSky that she too fancies a crack at the Tory leadership: "If people asked me, then of course I would give it serious thought”. Join the queue.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The only "meltdown" in Cabinet was from other ministers to stop Esther McVey's call for a vote around the table on the Brexit deal so they "didn't have to put their names to it", she tells @SophyRidgeSky. Ouch.
author: tnewtondunn

text: John McDonnell calling on “all Labour members” to join a counter demonstration against Tommy Robinson/UKIP’s Brexit protest in Whitehall tomorrow pm: “The working class of Britain have a proud history of beating the far right”. Unlikely this will end well.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Source close to Gavin Williamson: “It’s a case of what’s the worst risk - the severe embarrassment of pulling the vote, versus the end of today’s Conservative Party and letting in Jeremy Corbyn”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson warns Theresa May the Conservative Party could split up next week if she insists on holding the meaningful vote
author: tnewtondunn

text:
The full Hancock letter here. Brexiteers already questioning the timing, just four days ahead of the meaningful vote...
https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/762677/medicines-supply-contingency-plans-letter.pdf …
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here is the key bit of @MattHancock's letter to pharmaceutical companies and hospitals today. Prepare for 6 MONTHS of border chaos under No Deal...
author: tnewtondunn

text: I understand the Government has significantly revised up its worst case scenario on No Deal disruption at UK borders - to 6 months of chaos, rather than 6 weeks. Letters going out to ‘stakeholders’ today.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks!
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thank you Michael, but I’m not sure any any wiser than anyone else...
author: tnewtondunn

text: "I served in the Cameron Government, and then May's, I've been a member of the Conservative Party for two decades, and I voted for Brexit because I passionately believed in it. I loved all three, and now all three are in ruin. I'm very depressed". A senior Tory figure.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Former Remainer @JohnnyMercerUK reveals he will vote against Brexit deal - becoming 104th Tory MP to denounce it: “To force through this deal, crossing her own red lines, speaks to a democratic deficit that I have always spoken out against”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: 3.Rising Tory star and former Remainer @JohnnyMercerUK delivers fresh blow to PM by coming out against her Brexit deal, branding it “a total failure of the political class”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: 2. Cabinet ministers losing patience with PM’s ongoing refusal to share any Plan B with them. One of them tells me: "It feels just like the fiasco with the election manifesto last year”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit crisis latest: 1. Mood hardening among Tory loyalists for May to resign next week if/when she loses meaningful vote. One minister: “There is a feeling after Tuesday’s disaster that she has well and truly run out of road".
author: tnewtondunn

text: I learned tonight that Theresa May can't now pull the meaningful vote even if she wants to, without MPs' consent. Would need to win a new procedure motion... and it's unclear she would.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And in case anyone wondered, here is the full list of PM's trade envoys - including 15 (now-)loyal Tory backbenchers.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tory MPs can now rebel against 3 line whips on Brexit without fear of losing their Government jobs. To @edvaizey's immense relief, I'm told No10 has "no plans" to strip him of PM's Trade Envoy to Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos (good job that).
author: tnewtondunn

text: Mark Francois reveals a 74 year-old Chelsea pensioner ex-Royal Marine is being investigated for a legacy incident in Northern Ireland for which he was cleared years ago: “Please, please do something about it Prime Minister” #PMQs
author: tnewtondunn

text: Hmm. We’ll have to check, but don’t think so. There is currently no parliamentary veto on the backstop, just an ability to postpone it for 2 years.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Isn’t that vote only whether to extend the transition period? Backstop would remain in statute as the default.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Good story. But v unclear how many Brexiteers this would really persuade. Also if HMG did this, high likelihood EU27 would say UK in default of the agreement and EU Parliament would refuse to ratify.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The Govt is on its knees, Brexit is in crisis, and the Tory party in total disarray. But Jeremy Corbyn ignores all that to ask all 6 Qs about a worthy UN report on poverty. That’s some political judgement #PMQs
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks David, v kind
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brave bloke, putting his real name to his homophobia like that.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks Andy. Stig, hopefully noted.
author: tnewtondunn

text: That’s v kind thank you
author: tnewtondunn

text: Rather proud to be en route to College Green for the @SkyNews paper reviews tonight with @annabotting and my lecture theatre sofa wife formerly known as @ayeshahazarika.
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is quite something. 26 Tory MPs voted against Theresa May - including some big name loyalists; former ministers Damian Green, Sir Michael Fallon, Richard Benyon, Sir Oliver Letwin, Sir Nicholas Soames, Oliver Heald, Nick Boles and Ed Vaizey.
author: tnewtondunn

text: This means Parliament will try to take back control of Brexit, for example to (if there are the votes):  1. Stop no deal, 2. Join a customs union or EEA, 3. Enforce a 2nd referendum. Not legally binding on HMG, but politically will be almost impossible to ignore.
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is huge - MPs defeat Government to enforce their right to instruct the PM on what to do if she loses the meaningful vote next week; 321 v 299.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Legally no, politically yes.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Government agrees to publish the full legal advice provided to Cabinet by the Attorney General, but only after Privileges Committee scrutinises the decision.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Break: Government becomes the first in history to be found in contempt of Parliament for not publishing Brexit deal's full legal advice - loses knife edge vote by 311 v 293.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Government loses vote to pass contempt of Parliament punishment to Privileges Committee - IF it is upheld; 307 v 311.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here they are. Not only only do they debase their cause, it’s the opposite of British.
author: tnewtondunn

text: There are some unadulterated pond life on College Green at the moment, carrying Trump placards, barracking @OwenJones84 with appalling unprintable abuse. Whatever your politics, that is pathetic.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And that, incredibly ironically, could help the PM win over a few more Brexiteer MPs, who will shudder at the thought of that.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Big news: Dominic Grieve has asked for this amendment to be voted on tonight, Speaker is deciding. If it wins, Parliament will have wrestled control of Brexit's direction back from Govt if meaningful vote is lost.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The @OBR_UK fights back. On its Brexit forecasts, admits growth didn't slow as quickly as it predicted, but it has now - and it says it was also right on inflation rising and investment dropping.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Another eyewitness MP comes forward on Dining Room-gate to question loyalists' dismissal of the above account...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Wouldn’t that be for a fresh ECJ case to rule which side of the negotiation was being abusive? Jarndyce vs Jarndyce...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here’s a thought: will Brexiteers seize this as a way out of the backstop trap? If ECJ uphold advice, HMG could revoke A50 and then invoke it again the next day, resetting the clock for a new negotiation or an effective 2 year transition to WTO. Possibilities open up.
author: tnewtondunn

text: In other words, an eyewitness. Who I completely stand by and trust btw Matt, as this colleague of yours is not a toady on the payroll who'll say anything to get promoted.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Thanks Mark. I've QT'd some of your colleagues saying similar. Perhaps the unhappy MP (not at all a usual suspect btw) saw her on arrival. You're not disputing the rareness of her presence there though?
author: tnewtondunn

text: “I told her it was nothing personal and I respected her. Theresa just said, ‘Everybody says that to me, ‘you’ve done your best - but’’. She looked defeated to be honest.” Anti-Brexit deal Tory MP who saw the PM today.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Best news the PM has had all day. Former Brexit minister Lord Bridges - who called her negotiation “a gangplank into thin air” - has decided the deal is still worth voting for, as the least worst option.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Have you seen her in the dining room before Matt?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Others (@alexchalkchelt, @mattwarman too) dispute the PM’s discomfort - but not the immense rarity of seeing her there.
author: tnewtondunn

text: A sign of dire straits: the PM had dinner in Members’ Dining Room tonight - the first time she’s been seen in there for 10 years. An unimpressed Tory MP: “She didn’t know what to do, or where to get her food. I’ve never seen anything more desperate”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sign of our times: the DUP - the Government's own allies - join Labour, the SNP, Lib Dems, Plaid and the Greens to ask the Speaker to launch contempt proceedings against them.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cox: “But I am prepared to lend my support to it, because I do NOT believe”... (he thumps the Despatch Box, to Labour MPs’ tizzy fit ‘oooohh)...”I do NOT believe we will be entrapped in it permanently”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Geoffrey Cox, trying the masochism approach on the Irish backstop to MPs: “It will subsist. We are indefinitely committed to it. There’s no point in me or the Government trying to hide that”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: In summary: the 43 page legal advice summary is expansive, blunt and at times extremely painful reading for MPs. The only plus for HMG is that may negate some of the calls to see the whole thing.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Britain's rule taker status during the transition period is also writ large in the advice. For its duration (up to 3 years and 9 months), we are locked out of any decision making on EU rules, and may even be forbidden from seeing security info.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here is a stinker for Leavers hoping to just get Brexit over the line and then renegotiate the lot of it. Any PM who rips up the deal will be breaking the law.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And on the backstop's review mechanism: a breach of negotiating in good faith is only provable if there is "a clear basis"; ie not just one side's say so.  This is quite a high bar.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The key paragraph. The Irish backstop "will continue to apply unless and until it is superseded, in whole or in part, by a subsequent agreement establishing alternative arrangements". ie, it is indefinite.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Just published - the Government's legal advice on the Brexit deal (a summary, not the whole thing) 
https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/761153/EU_Exit_-_Legal_position_on_the_Withdrawal_Agreement.pdf …
author: tnewtondunn

text: Theresa May yet again refuses to categorically rule out holding a 2nd referendum as PM. Just vents her opposition to one: "People are talking about a second vote. We need to deliver on the first vote". Why won't she do that? #ThisMorning
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sajid Javid reveals he was physically attacked and racially abused for being Asian in a school playground, aged 11.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sajid Javid refuses even to say that a fall in net EU immigration is a good thing. It is current Govt policy to aim for precisely this - the 100,000 target.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sajid Javid now admits it’s “very unlikely” the immigration white paper will be published before the meaningful vote. He was due to publish it tomorrow, before an enormous row with No10 @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Your country needs Q: Chief of MI6 calls for new generation of techno-smart spies to sign up and fight Russia’s hybrid war;
author: tnewtondunn

text: And you're obviously a snob.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Genuine pond life. And this was in the first half when they were winning #AFCvTHFC
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is @SamGyimah’s central argument⁩ for resigning. If Brexiteers can’t stand the backstop, Remainers can’t abide the vagueness of the Political Declaration, which they say the EU will (again) ruthlessly exploit. https://www.facebook.com/204388219715107/posts/1170464863107433/ …
author: tnewtondunn

text: Universities Minister @SamGyimah’s resignation tonight now makes that 65 declared. So Govt could lose the meaningful vote by 183.
author: tnewtondunn

text: This quite closely matches the estimate we reported this week by a May loyalist ex-minister. So, No10 have to turn 80% of the current Tory rebels to have any chance.
author: tnewtondunn

text: An excellent count of Tory MPs opposing Brexit deal here by @ConHome; 64 declared they’ll vote against, 27 probably will, 7 might. If all do, plus DUP, and 20 Labour MPs vote for it, Govt loses by 181.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Corbyn accused of “running scared” of BBC’s Brexit TV debate proposal for a panel of experts to grill the two leaders about alternatives;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Spirraling terrorist violence only “the tip of the iceberg” of a new tidal wave of fanaticism in UK - Extremism Commissioner Sara Khan’s shock warning;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Emotional moment in Commons - Labour MP Lloyd Russell-Moyle close to tears as he tells MPs he is HIV positive, and has been for 9 years. Colleagues surround him in support.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I also hear that the BBC's debate will not be hosted by @afneil. A shame, but unsurprising neither May nor Corbyn would agree to that type of box office savaging.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Interesting. I'm told BBC are promising a far bigger audience because their debate would follow Strictly's result show. On same Sunday last year in 8pm slot, BBC had 11.9m viewers, vs ITV's 4m. I’m A Celeb's big audience bounce only kicks in at 9pm when it starts.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Unsure how good a look it is for the BBC to bolster No10's case (or ITV to aide Corbyn's) in this Tory v Labour spat. Better to leave it to the politicians to fight it out.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Labour party spokesman: "Negotiations about the debate are still ongoing". Fury in Team Corbyn, accusing No10 of trying to bounce them.
author: tnewtondunn

text: BUT hang on: This is still dependent on Labour agreeing. Corbyn said to prefer ITV's pitch - not least because of its 7pm start time, avoiding a clash with I'm A Celebrity. All still in play, I'm told.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking - BBC wins broadcasters race to host Brexit deal debate on Sunday December 9, at 8pm.
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM cannot confirm that the Immigration white paper will be published before the meaningful vote (nb - it was gridded by No10 for December 4, before an almighty Cabinet row) #LiaisonCommittee
author: tnewtondunn

text: If it's no longer a marriage, will it be "friends with benefits" with the EU after Brexit, @TomTugendhat asks? General smutty laughter. PM appears to be the only one not to get the joke #LiaisonCommittee
author: tnewtondunn

text: Killer question from @YvetteCooperMP: "Prime Minister, I’ve known you for 20 years. Are you the kind of person who could bring in a no deal? Because I don’t believe you are". May, inevitably, ducks: "It's a decision for Parliament" #LiaisonCommittee
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here's the quote.. PM: "What the analysis shows is there will be an impact on the rate of growth. But there are many variables that will change. It doesn’t deal with all the decisions that the government might take" (eg, making new trade deals)
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM refuses to admit that leaving EU under every scenario will hurt growth because HMT's forecasts are flawed. That's quite a claim #LiaisonCommittee
author: tnewtondunn

text: Understatement of the day - PM: "If I’m being honest with you, we haven’t persuaded absolutely everybody in Europe about frictionless trade yet" #LiaisonCommittee
author: tnewtondunn

text: Well done cover girl and sofa wife, ⁦@ayeshahazarika⁩. Ni-Mai  agreed.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: No10 forced to rip up bid to use NHS’s 10-year plan to sell the Brexit deal after row with health bosses.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tracey Crouch, Ministerial Resignation of the Year, does a Trumpington at the Chancellor #SpecAwards
author: tnewtondunn

text:
A standing ovation for the legendary Frank Field, Parliamentarian of the Year
#SpecAwards
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cabinet Resignation of the Year, shared by Dominic Raab and David Davis - ⁦⁦@FraserNelson⁩: “The first 2 Brexit Secretaries of 2018” #SpecAwards
author: tnewtondunn

text: Margaret Hodge, collecting Speech of the Year award: “My father tried to make me Jewish and failed. The local rabbi tried to make me Jewish and failed. It took the Leader of the Labour Party to do that” #SpecAwards
author: tnewtondunn

text: Very good but highly risqué speech by Liz Truss at the #SpecAwards. Best gag: “When Ruth Davidson’s son grows up, I hope he lives long enough to see us get out of the backstop”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Police Minister Nick Hurd picks a winner, eats it, and winks. Nicked.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The DUP has just voted with the Government (for the first time in 2 weeks) to defeat a Labour amendment on the Offensive Weapons Bill. The best news the PM has had all week.
author: tnewtondunn

text: That's one helluva Nike tick (copyright B.Johnson)
author: tnewtondunn

text: The Cabinet’s next dilemma. Can they win over enough Stephen Kinnocks (76 Labour MPs have already voted for EEA) to outweigh the ERG’s ranks at the time (40-80)?
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is what Theresa May told me on Monday about today's Brexit forecasts. Basically, don't trust them, especially if they say staying in the EU is better than my deal. I wonder if @HMTreasury agrees with her?
author: tnewtondunn

text: 1. It can. Parliament is sovereign, it does what it wants. 2. It can be, by unanimous agreement of the EU28 (as stated in Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty). 3. That’s between you and it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: I’m used to it. She’s looked at me disapprovingly like that for 28 years now
author: tnewtondunn

text: My great uncle Tommy. A truly lovely man.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Cabinet minister: “Theresa is still being told she can win this by the people around her in No10. It’s terrible advice and she deserves better, because they are going to bring her down”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Cabinet ministers weigh up whether to urge PM to abandon meaningful vote on Brexit deal to avoid massive defeat by 200;
author: tnewtondunn

text: All quiet in politics at the moment isn’t it?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Five month Labour probe finally clears @IanAustinMP of being abusive after he called the party "a sewer" of antisemitism.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Patrick O'Flynn resigns from UKIP to join... "the resurgent SDP" (who are now eurosceptic). When did they last have an MEP or MP, the 1980s?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Wonder if he has anyone in mind?
author: tnewtondunn

text: I assure you I’m not defending anybody. Not my job to do that.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Amid all the excitement about Sir Michael Fallon’s very legitimate criticisms about May’s deal, it’s also worth remembering she fired him for sexual impropriety a year ago and he has never forgiven her. Just saying, as they say.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And; May insists a controversial knighthood given to eurosceptic Sir John Hayes had been agreed with him as far back as January: "This has been misconstrued”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: PM also risks controversy by downplaying Government’s own economic assessment of her Brexit deal: “It is very difficult to forecast the state of the economy".
author: tnewtondunn

text: May also hits back at Emmanuel Macron by threatening to ban French fishing boats if he blackmails Britain over Irish backstop: "So whose fishermen would be able to fish in UK waters?”
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: PM offers olive branch to win back DUP - rest of UK may voluntarily keep same rules and regulations as NI during Irish backstop (interview with @SunPolitics);
author: tnewtondunn

text: But: the provisional date for it - evening of Sunday December 9 - clashes with the @ImACelebrity final. What to do?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Theresa May today challenges Jeremy Corbyn to a historic live TV debate on her Brexit deal - "I have got a plan. He hasn’t";
author: tnewtondunn

text: His very own fake news. My favourite breaking news alert for quite a while.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Really? What about Hammond stubbornness on no deal prep? Or Boris’s showboating ego?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Where did HMG go wrong in the Brexit negotiation? ⁦@nick_gutteridge⁩ and I detail the 5 key mistakes today (spoiler: it’s far from all Theresa May’s fault).
author: tnewtondunn

text: Vernon Bogdanor suggests the way to solve what question to ask at a second EU referendum is to hold 2 - 1st: In/Out, 2nd: (if Out) what type of Out, May’s deal/No deal. Then presumably, none ever ever again... @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sure. The article covers that. The idea is dependent on 2nd referendum amendment failing.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Revealed - Theresa May launches 17 day campaign to save her Brexit deal after setting December 12 as date for meaningful vote;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Cabinet ministers plan for Britain to join EFTA with 76 Labour rebels’ help - after Brexit deal, general election and second referendum all fail;
author: tnewtondunn

text:
May: “This is the best possible deal, it's the only possible deal"
Juncker: "This is the best deal possible for Britain. This is the only deal possible".
Someone's been comparing notes #EUCO
author: tnewtondunn

text: Replies to the below suggest they do... and will.
author: tnewtondunn

text: And, in response to @Daily_Express, May also refuses to categorically rule out EEA membership as a fall back. There's a lot not ruled out there.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Will you rule out attaching a second referendum to the deal at the meaningful vote or forming a Govt of National Unity, PM is asked by @SunPolitics? She refused to be categorical on either. Hmm. #EUCO
author: tnewtondunn

text: George is here, @theresa_may. Phew.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
End of Brexit summit press conferences begin. Tone is sorrow not triumph.
Tusk: "We will remain friends until the end of days, and one day longer".
Juncker: "We're not raising champagne glasses. It is a sad day".
#EUCO
author: tnewtondunn

text: So much for a frantic through the night final negotiation... the deal summit has actually wrapped up five minutes early (11.55am rather than 12pm).
author: tnewtondunn

text: Yes it does.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Plus you cannot deny it’s going to make negotiating a future deal for Gibraltar harder now, surely? In summary, far from terminal for Gib sovereignty of course but not ideal...
author: tnewtondunn

text: But HMG opposed this Bob when it first appeared in EUCO’s A50 negotiating guidelines.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Sure, technically if not in reality. But not every EU member state gets to have its own bilateral agreement about UK dependencies. Plus HMG opposed this.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Turns out you make the cut for my DP list too Paul , along with @MrHarryCole, @Peston, @PickardJE, @SamCoatesTimes and @business. What’s the algorithm, how many times you’ve searched them?
author: tnewtondunn

text: So Spain gets its veto on any future EU trade deal for Gibraltar after all - an original A50 demand. HMG opposed this for two years, but concedes defeat at the very last moment. Not an ideal look.
author: tnewtondunn

text: “Could I suggest a crest with an utter cock rampant on one side and a big chicken on the other?” Bravo Mark Francois and @IainDale
author: tnewtondunn

text: Fancy that. No10 has, out of the blue, just given long standing eurosceptic Tory MP John Hayes a knighthood. Two unrelated facts: he didn't sign a no confidence letter, and hasn't yet said he'll vote down the Brexit deal.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Big: Theresa May refuses to rule out resigning as PM three times if her Brexit deal falls in the Commons: To @Emmabarnett: "This is not about me". New message to Tory MPs - my deal, or party chaos if I go.
author: tnewtondunn

text: What’s the real significance of the ‘all things to all men’ vagueness of the Political Declaration? There will be years (3-5 minimum?) of more rows about what EU trade deal we want. Hence, the internecine Tory civil war over it has only just begun.
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 have just given wavering Labour MPs yet another reason to vote for a 2nd referendum amendment...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Corbyn’s best response: “The blindfold Brexit from a Government that spent more time negotiating with itself than for the nation - 26 pages, that’s one a month”. He ain’t wrong either.
author: tnewtondunn

text: It’s quite something when the PM’s only new argument on the day she finally unveils a full Brexit deal is “the British people want this settled”. She also ain’t wrong. So the biggest bet of her Premiership is ennui will win the day.
author: tnewtondunn

text: More than 100 Tory MPs could vote against PM’s Brexit deal, rebels claim, giving it “zero chance” of passing now;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Latest: I understand British and EU negotiators will now talk through the night tonight. If they go well, there could well be a new draft Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration published tomorrow afternoon. So somebody is blinking... we'll soon find out who.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Philip Hammond reveals his morning glory. @GuardianAnushka: Do you write your own Budget jokes? Chx: "Yes. Usually they come to me first thing in the morning when I wake up”#Peston
author: tnewtondunn

text: Theresa May reveals she will be "returning to Brussels on Saturday" to try to finalise a Brexit deal with Jean-Clause Juncker. But... Angela Merkel has refused to come to Sunday's summit unless a deal is done tomorrow. Rock versus hard place.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Another serious problem for the PM, pointed out by @NigelDoddsDUP. There is no mention of the Stormont lock on regulatory changes for NI in the Withdrawal Agreement. Does this not put the PM herself in breach of Good Friday? No10 cannot explain the contradiction.
author: tnewtondunn

text: An excellent first question from Corbyn, followed by 5 sub-standard waffley soundbites. Result, lucky May let off the hook. How does he achieve this every single week? #PMQs
author: tnewtondunn

text: Liz Truss has abandoned No10's 'PM's deal or no deal' line altogether, for a new binary choice of Brexit/no Brexit. Tells @Emmabarnett: “If my colleagues don’t sign up to this in Parliament, we’re in grave danger of not leaving at all”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Rudd is right, but she’s back in the Cabinet now and has just given Brexiteer and Remain rebels a free pass to throw it out. What on earth now for No10’s collapsing communications strategy?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Uh oh. Amber Rudd publicly dismisses PM’s biggest reason for MPs to vote for her Brexit deal, to avoid no deal: “The House of Commons will stop no deal. There isn’t a majority for that to take place” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is quite serious. The DUP going on strike reduces the Govt's majority to around 3 - in effect pretty much paralysing it from daring to pass any new laws until a solution to the Brexit impasse is found.
author: tnewtondunn

text: The DUP will abstain again on all Finance Bill votes tonight, sources confirm, plus probably other Govt legislation if tabled next week.  They are now effectively on strike (and the confidence and supply agreement all but suspended) until the Irish backstop is resolved.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Max Fac is back... No10 says Cabinet today discussed the new “alternative arrangements” option to avoid the Irish backstop (which we revealed last night), and how technological solutions could do that. Fresh work now under way on it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Kinda immaterial if they vote for her now. Big if still though.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Agreed. But perhaps they’ll be ready by 2022 after a 12 month transition extension? Who knows.
author: tnewtondunn

text: That’s a trade deal isn’t it? Alternative arrangements is... alternative arrangements. Straw clutching it may be, but the Brexiteers are biting.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Here is that crucial “alternative arrangements” clause. The final paragraph in the below. Buried on p304 of the Withdrawal Agreement, but No10 hope it’s the “magic bullet”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: This is what Iain Duncan-Smith’s delegation of senior Brexiteers went to see the PM about this afternoon. They left No10 tight-lipped, but sources said it was “a constructive meeting”. Will it be enough to win them round?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Revealed - Theresa May’s secret plan to scrap the Irish backstop to win round angry Brexiteers. EU has agreed to allow “alternative arrangements” to keep the border open IF she can prove max fac works (it’s a big if).
author: tnewtondunn

text: 4. Here’s how that vote went: the minority Govt (Tories alone) still narrowly won it, versus every other party in the Commons. This is more than embarrassing for Labour’s chief whip.
author: tnewtondunn

text: 3. It’s a great irony that Labour hasn’t got the discipline to muster enough of their own MPs through the division lobbies to defeat the Govt even when the DUP vote with them. They couldn’t tonight.
author: tnewtondunn

text: 2. So what does Theresa May do about it? Technically, she should suspend any further payment of the £2bn of taxpayers’ money that the DUP have twisted out of her as their price. But she won’t.
author: tnewtondunn

text: 1. By voting against the Govt on the Finance Bill tonight (to back a Corbyn amendment), has the DUP broken the confidence and supply agreement? Here’s the wording - it’s pretty clear it has.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Delighted you're joining @SunPolitics Jack and looking forward to seeing you (window seat undergoing deep clean now).
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 say PM is adamant transition extension must end before next general election (June 2022). Six months earlier than Barnier... but 6 years after the referendum, to the very month.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Brexiteers still at least 6 MPs short of triggering confidence vote in PM - 48 needed, but only 42 assurances given to ERG (25 publicly, 17 in private). And that’s only if all telling the truth...
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit latest: May risks two more Cabinet resignations after refusing to negotiate Irish backstop - but Gove will stay on until the end;
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Tory leadership vote latest: a mathematics debate may decide the PM's future...
ERG sources suggest the letters threshold may be 47 not 48, as two MPs (Charlie Elphicke and Andrew Griffiths) are still suspended. 15% of 315 is 47.25. 
So is Graham Brady allowed to round down?!
author: tnewtondunn

text: Seconded, congrats Chopper!
author: tnewtondunn

text: The very able @KwasiKwarteng promoted to be a junior DexEU minister. Surprising it's taken No10 this long to give him a Govt job. A Brexiteer.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Two troublemakers and ex-ministers back in Govt - Remainer Stephen Hammond to health, and John Penrose to Northern Ireland. No10 are bridge building fast.
author: tnewtondunn

text: But, a big but: Brexit Sec role is being stripped down, just now the domestic delivery of Brexit. PM will have sole charge of the final negotiations.
author: tnewtondunn

text: New Brexit Secretary is Steven Barclay, a mid ranking health minister and former whip (who voted Leave).
author: tnewtondunn

text: Confirmed: Michael Gove is not resigning and will stay on as Environment Secretary.
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 now clarify: there will be no free vote for any Tory MPs, ministers or otherwise, on the Brexit deal.
author: tnewtondunn

text: A full 36 hours on from the Brexit deal being published, it is striking that No10 cannot persuade a single Leave backing minister on to broadcast to defend it.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
May refuses 3 times to answer whether the Cabinet will get a free vote on her deal - Penny Mordaunt's demand. "There is collective responsibility. The Government will put its position to the House of Commons"
It would be extraordinary if she conceded this #LBC
author: tnewtondunn

text: May reveals she faces personal risk from medicine supplies drying up under no deal: "I'm a type 1 diabetic. I need insulin every day. As it happens mine is produced by a company in the European Union" #LBC
author: tnewtondunn

text: Theresa May dismisses claim that the DUP have demanded her resignation: "I haven’t had a testy exchange with Arlene on that. We’re still working with the DUP" #LBC
author: tnewtondunn

text: Tory ministers initiate secret talks with moderate Labour MPs for a Government of National Unity if May falls behind No10’s back;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: Philip Hammond pleads with big business to help save the Brexit deal in night conference call - we’ve seen the transcript;
author: tnewtondunn

text: I am told neither Michael Gove nor Penny Mordaunt are expected to resign tonight, though both are still in the balance.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Rory Stewart attacks Jacob Rees-Mogg and the ERG as “pompous people producing medieval fantasies” for suggesting vassalage, on @SkyNews.
Gloves totally off now, (another) full blown Tory civil war begins.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Michael Gove has pulled out of a speech to farmers in North Yorkshire today, but for very genuine family reasons.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Graham Brady says he has no plans to make any public statement today. At the moment, anyway. (Rules crib: the first we'd hear of a confidence vote in a Tory leader is when the 1922 chair announces it).
author: tnewtondunn

text: George is rather enjoying today. Revenge, cold dish, served.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Francois also claims 84 Tory MPs will now vote against her deal, as well as Labour, DUP, SNP: “It is mathematically impossible to get this deal through the House of Commons”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: ERG vice chair Mark Francois tells PM her Brexit deal is “deal on arrival in St Tommys” and pleads with her “to accept the political reality you face”. Does that mean go?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Peter Bottomley is the first Tory MP to back the PM in the Commons, a full 57 minutes after her statement began.
author: tnewtondunn

text: DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds tells PM her deal is “a vote for a vassal state to break up the United Kingdom”. Says no point in saying more, as “she doesn’t listen”. 10 votes gone.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Extraordinary scenes in the Commons. John Redwood getting shouted down by his own Tory MP colleagues, almost every Labour MP standing to be called for a question.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Corbyn demands May withdraws “this half-baked deal” which isn’t supported by the Cabinet or the country.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Promotion to Cabinet I expect... Stewart is a deal loyalist (a rare thing)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Michael Gove is currently not on the front bench for PM’s statement. Jeremy Hunt and Sajid Javid are though.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Suella Braverman has reportedly resigned from DExEU.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Esther McVey quits. Third minister to go today, second from Cabinet.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Raab says he is not calling for May to go, and is not launching his own leadership challenge. This is a resignation on principle, he says.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Theresa May is now in very severe trouble. All eyes now on @michaelgove, @Jeremy_Hunt and @sajidjavid. If they go too today too, it’s over for her.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Raab resigns. I’ve just spoken to him: “I don’t want to submit to the blackmail of my country”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: We wait with extreme interest. Where too is @michaelgove? Or Hunt and Javid? You either own this under collective responsibility, or you resign. Time’s up for cake and eating it.
author: tnewtondunn

text: It’s the morning after the Brexit deal was agreed, a momentous moment. So why isn’t the Brexit Secretary himself @DominicRaab on broadcast defending it? He hasn’t even tweeted about it yet.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Northern Ireland minister Shailesh Vara resigns in protest at Brexit deal leaving UK “half in, half out”
author: tnewtondunn

text: Wow. Nick Timothy claims tonight that Theresa May NEVER thought Brexit could succeed. Writes in @Telegraph: "British negotiators have shown by their actions that they never believed Brexit can be a success. This includes, I say with the heaviest of hearts, the Prime Minister".
author: tnewtondunn

text: Friends of Graham Brady say he went to see the PM tonight to discuss the Brexit deal (not a confidence vote). Stand down... for now.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Big Brexit news: it appears Chequers has been chucked. A senior Govt source has refused to say PM is still pushing for an FCA or Common Rulebook in future trade deal: “We may get frictionless trade through another way”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: No Cabinet minister has resigned rather than back May's deal, No10 sources say. At least, not yet.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
PM says choice before MPs is her deal, or no deal and risk "no Brexit at all". 
Adds: "I know there will be difficult days ahead". She ain't wrong there.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Break: Theresa May confirms Cabinet has agreed her Brexit divorce deal with the EU after "a long detailed and impassioned debate".
author: tnewtondunn

text: who said that?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Latest: Cabinet is overrunning, and considerably. I understand every member wants to have a very long say. Now not expected to finish until at least 6pm, possibly even 7pm.
author: tnewtondunn

text: A little hard to understand why MPs think they should come before millions of their own voters today, who the media directly serve.
author: tnewtondunn

text: New IMF Brexit analysis: Britain will lose four years of economic growth (6% percent of GDP) if there is a no deal Brexit. By extraordinary timing, this is published this afternoon.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Kindness to lobby hacks perhaps, Sir Nick?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Significant, from a longterm foe of the PM. Best news she's had all day so far.
author: tnewtondunn

text: “Old tramp”?!
author: tnewtondunn

text: Theresa May agrees to look at banning the online sale of crossbows in the Offensive Weapons Bill... that is, if the Govt ever dares to bring it back to the Commons (pulled twice so far) #PMQs
author: tnewtondunn

text: I’m told Penny Mordaunt is awaiting further assurances before she puts her name to the Brexit deal, having now read it and seen PM. But allies warn “don't expect fireworks today” from her.
author: tnewtondunn

text: ERG vice chair Mark Francois turns up the pressure: “This will be the most important decision they ever make in their whole lives. If the Prime Minister bludgeons it through, they will have to take a very important decision and history will judge them” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: He’s right about the knob bit though eh.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Hague describes DUP’s refusal to back the deal as “very concerning”. Adds: “The Cabinet will need to take that into account” and continue to prepare for no deal too if it falls in Commons.
author: tnewtondunn

text: William Hague previews No10’s sales pitch for the deal. UK gets its own immigration policy and no more ‘big’ payments to Brussels, but: “It’s true there are many compromises, but did anyone think we’d be able to leave the EU without them?” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: I’m just reporting it. Not saying I believe it or not... don’t shoot the messenger over the next very choppy 4 weeks please!
author: tnewtondunn

text: Business begins to speak. Siemens’ Jürgen Maier: “My gut feeling is we need to get behind this deal and make it work. What business needs is certainly and this seems to be the only deal in town” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: Final thought for tonight: I hear the draft Future Framework will also be published tomorrow. It’s only 15 pages long and means all things to all men, Chequers as well as Canada. It will either fool everyone or no one.
author: tnewtondunn

text: ...but, Cabinet expected to last at least 3 hours tomorrow afternoon, so it’s going to be another long night.
author: tnewtondunn

text: If Cabinet agrees the deal, No10 will begin a massive sales job immediately tomorrow night. All 500 pages of the divorce deal will be published in full, and PM will give a live TV press conference.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Most ominous moment in Cabinet today: Penny Mordaunt asked the PM to suspend collective responsibility to give all ministers a free vote on her deal in Commons. PM didn’t respond (ht @MrHarryCole).
author: tnewtondunn

text: No10 source says PM will tell Cabinet the negotiation “has been pushed as far as it can go” and the UK “cannot get any better deal than this one”. Adds: “The PM is firmly of the view that the deal will not be improved by dragging it out any longer”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: One gloomy Cabinet source: “The sad reality of where we are now is a bad deal is better than no deal. There is no time left to stop no deal becoming a disaster”.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
The detail on the Irish backstop:
1. A UK-wide customs union, and no NI-only version (UK win)
2. An independent panel to arbitrate a ‘good faith’ end mechanism (UK win)
3. No backstop end date or time limit (UK loss)
4. Full level playing field rules apply thru out (UK loss)
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit deal latest: Cabinet sources say May’s pivotal 5 senior ministers - Raab, Hunt, Javid, Gove and Cox - will back it. Leadsom and Grayling also on board. McVey and Mordaunt so far not.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Boris Johnson tells @BBCPolitics that PM's deal is "a chronicle of a death foretold" and "vassal state stuff", as UK will be staying in large parts of the single market and a customs union. "Am I going to vote against it? The answer is yes".
author: tnewtondunn

text: I am told Cabinet was roundly bollocked by Theresa May today for leaking from it. She blamed leaks last week for the humble address defeat today, and asked them to stop. That too has now leaked.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Cabinet ministers are being called into No10 to see the PM one by one tonight ahead of full Cabinet meeting tomorrow to sign off Brexit divorce deal. Endgame is beginning.
author: tnewtondunn

text:
Nigel Dodds is coming very close to breaking the confidence and supply agreement with the Govt if his MPs vote with Labour this afternoon. On Brexit policy: "The DUP agrees to support the Government in votes in the UK Parliament".
https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/621794/Confidence_and_Supply_Agreement_between_the_Conservative_Party_and_the_DUP.pdf …
author: tnewtondunn

text: David Lidington offers MPs a compromise on publishing Brexit deal legal advice, with an offer of “access to detailed legal analysis”. Is it enough to buy off the ERG and DUP?
author: tnewtondunn

text: This works well for Macron too. A bit of Trump-bashing is popular in France.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Zut alors. 'You'd be speaking German now if it wasn't for US...' etc. Bromance properly over.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Speaker Bercow has just banned mimicking of any accents in Parliament, even in friendly jest, after @JonathanPlaid complained that a Tory MP abused him about his Welsh accent.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Intriguingly though, No10 did not deny the below from the very well connected @tombradby when I put it to PMOS;
author: tnewtondunn

text: Negotiations latest: PM told Cabinet this morning that progress has been made in the last 24 hours, but there "remain a small number of outstanding issues". No deal today, but Cabinet could well be summoned to sign one off tomorrow.
author: tnewtondunn

text: "You might as well get Mr Blobby on to give his analysis". @ChrisMasonBBC speaks for all of Westminster.
author: tnewtondunn

text: De facto deputy PM David Lidington says a Breixt deal by Wednesday night’s deadline is “possible but not at all definite”. He is “cautiously optimistic” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: This would be the 3rd in a week, after FOBTs and Brexit deal legal advice. Not governing but drowning?
author: tnewtondunn

text: Six Tory MPs sign amendment to force Govt to publish Treasury’s assessment of EU membership v May’s deal. Another defeat possible.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Excl: More than 40 Tory MPs to rebel against Theresa May today after ERG tables its own bid to force publication of full legal advice on Brexit deal
author: tnewtondunn

text: Latest on #BrexitGroundhogDay: May turns down fudged Brexit deal fearing Commons would shoot it down. No10 now aiming for EU summit on Dec 4-5
author: tnewtondunn

text: Also: Whitehall sources say the Withdrawal Agreement is currently around 400 pages long. Oh the impending joy.
author: tnewtondunn

text: A bitter irony: as a campaigner and prominent QC, Lester was one of the architects of Britain’s ground-breaking race and sex equality laws in the 60s and 70s.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Breaking: Lord Lester suspended for almost 4 years over for demanding sex in exchange for help to pass legislation. This was our story that revealed the scandal;
author: tnewtondunn

text: So, the likelihood is now a December 13/14 summit, which pushes the Meaningful Vote into January. Will be very tight to pass all the ensuing Brexit deal legislation in less than 3 months, meaning Article 50 could have to be extended by a month or two.
author: tnewtondunn

text: More: Tusk has told No10 that a deadline for a November summit is this Wednesday night. But it appears the Govt is beginning to give up hope for one. Whitehall source: "I wouldn't get your hopes up".
author: tnewtondunn

text: Brexit negotiations latest: Olly Robbins and Sabine Weyand only broke up at 2.45am this morning, but without success. No10: “There are substantial issues still to overcome”.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Penny Mordaunt: "There are two checks on this deal. There is Cabinet, and there is Parliament". It's what we all know, but still a stunning public statement - PM vs her own Government.
author: tnewtondunn

text: Keir Starmer contradicts Jeremy Corbyn to insist the Labour Party’s official position is to keep stopping Brexit as an option: “I’m not going to pretend there aren’t different views” @BBCr4today
author: tnewtondunn

text: The changing face of a continent, during and after the Berlin Wall, through its passport covers. @YankoTihov's Europe lenticular. Cleverest art work I've ever seen, and pretty pertinent right now (sold by @TAGFineArts).
author: tnewtondunn

text: Who’s the missing elephant in the tweet?
author: tnewtondunn

text: I very much doubt Jo will be the last Remainer to resign from the Govt to vote for a 2nd referendum. At least four others in the mid ranks have been on the verge for several months.
author: tnewtondunn

text: So in summary: all of a sudden, there is a 'landing strip' (dire phrase I know) for a backstop deal, and hence a wider Withdrawal Agreement. But the devil as always will be in Geoffrey Cox's detail, and there is zero time left for shenanigans.
